'''Deep dyslexia ''' is a form of [[dyslexia]] that disrupts [[Reading (process)|reading processes]]. Deep dyslexia may occur as a result of a [[head injury]], [[stroke]], [[Neurological disorder|disease]], or [[Neurosurgery|operation]].<ref name=Harley>{{cite book| last=Harley| first=Trevor A.| title=The psychology of language: from data to theory| publisher=Taylor & Francis| year=2001| pages=189–195| isbn=978-0-86377-867-4 |oclc = 469913878 }}</ref> This injury results in the occurrence of [[Semantics|semantic]] errors during reading and the impairment of nonword reading.<ref name= "Colangelo" /><ref name= "Buchanan">{{cite journal|last=Buchanan|first=Lori|author2=McEwen, Shannon |author3=Westbury, Chris |author4= Libben, Gary |title=Semantics and semantic errors: Implicit access to semantic information from words and nonwords in deep dyslexia|journal=Brain and Language|year=2003|volume=84|issue=1|pages=65–83|doi=10.1016/S0093-934X(02)00521-7}}<!--|accessdate=19 March 2013--></ref>
The term [[dyslexia]] comes from the [[Greek language|Greek]] words 'dys' meaning 'impaired', and 'lexis' meaning 'word' and is used to describe disorders of language concerning reading and [[spelling]].
Numerous models and hypotheses have been proposed in attempt to explain the broad range of symptoms experienced by deep dyslexics, but a definite consensus has yet to be reached. The proposed models and hypotheses have helped in treatment of some suffering patients, but only with certain specific symptoms. Additionally, the recovery seen is not experienced equally in all patients.
==Classification== [[File:Brain trauma CT.jpg|thumb|[[Computerized tomography]] (CT) scan showing brain multiple [[frontal lobe|frontal]], [[parietal lobe|parietal]], and [[temporal lobe]] lesions.<ref name="Rehman08">{{cite journal |vauthors=Rehman T, Ali R, Tawil I, Yonas H |title=Rapid progression of traumatic bifrontal contusions to transtentorial herniation: A case report |journal=Cases Journal |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=203 |year=2008 |pmid=18831756 |pmc=2566562 |doi=10.1186/1757-1626-1-203 |url= http://www.casesjournal.com/content/1/1/203}}</ref> The cause of deep dyslexia is damage in the left hemisphere of the brain]]
Deep dyslexia is usually classified as an ''acquired reading disorder'', as opposed to a ''developmental dyslexia'', in previously literate adults as a consequence of a [[brain injury]].<ref name= "Colangelo">{{cite journal|last=Colangelo|first=Annette|author2=Buchanan, Lori|title=Localizing damage in the functional architecture: The distinction between implicit and explicit processing in deep dyslexia|journal=Journal of Neurolinguistics|year=2007|volume=20|issue=2|pages=111–144|doi=10.1016/j.jneuroling.2006.08.001}}<!--|accessdate=17 March 2013--></ref><ref name= "Colangelokaren">{{cite journal|last=Colangelo|first=Annette|author2=Buchanan, Lori|title=Implicit and explicit processing in deep dyslexia: Semantic blocking as a test for failure of inhibition in the phonological output lexicon|journal=Brain and Language|year=2006|volume=99|issue=3|pages=258–271|doi=10.1016/j.bandl.2005.07.048}}</ref><ref name= "Temple">{{cite journal|last=Temple|first=CM|title=Developmental and acquired dyslexias.|journal=Cortex|year=2006|volume=42|issue=6|pages=898–910|pmid=17131596|doi=10.1016/S0010-9452(08)70434-9}}</ref><ref name= "Coslett">{{cite journal|last=Coslett|first=HB|title=Acquired dyslexia.|journal=Seminars in neurology|year=2000|volume=20|issue=4|pages=419–26|pmid=11149697|doi=10.1055/s-2000-13174}}</ref> However, recently, developmental deep dyslexia has also been reported in children with [[Williams syndrome]].<ref name= "Temple" /><ref>{{cite journal|last=Johnston|first=RS|title=Developmental deep dyslexia?|journal=Cortex|year=1983|volume=19|issue=1|pages=133–9|pmid=6851588|doi=10.1016/s0010-9452(83)80057-4}}</ref>
Deep dyslexia is considered to be a "[[central dyslexia]]" as compared to a "[[peripheral dyslexia]]". Peripheral dyslexics have difficulty matching the visual characteristics of letters that comprise a word to a stored memory of this word from prior encounters.<ref name= "Coslett" /> Central dyslexics are unable to properly match the visual word to the word's meaning.<ref name= "Coslett" /> They may also be incapable of speaking, or [[Phonation|phonating]], the sequence of written letters that they see into the word these letters represent.<ref name= "Coslett" /> Deep dyslexia differs from other forms of central dyslexia ([[phonological dyslexia]] and [[surface dyslexia]]) in that deep dyslexics have many more symptoms and these symptoms are generally more severe.<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Rapcsak">{{cite journal|last=Rapcsak|first=Steven Z.|author2=Beeson, Pélagie M. |author3=Henry, Maya L. |author4=Leyden, Anne |author5=Kim, Esther |author6=Rising, Kindle |author7=Andersen, Sarah |author8= Cho, HyeSuk |title=Phonological dyslexia and dysgraphia: Cognitive mechanisms and neural substrates|journal=Cortex|year=2009|volume=45|issue=5|pages=575–591|doi=10.1016/j.cortex.2008.04.006 |pmid=18625494 |pmc=2689874}}</ref><ref name= "Orden">{{cite journal|last=Van Orden|first=G|title=What do double dissociations prove?|journal=Cognitive Science|year=2001|volume=25|issue=1|pages=111–172|doi=10.1016/S0364-0213(00)00036-7}}</ref> According to the "continuum" hypothesis, deep dyslexia is a more severe form of phonological dyslexia.<ref name= "Rapcsak" /><ref name= "Orden" /><ref name= "Lambon">{{cite journal|last=Lambon Ralph|first=Matthew A.|author2=Graham, Naida L.|title=Acquired phonological and deep dyslexia|journal=Neurocase|year=2000|volume=6|issue=2|pages=141–178|doi=10.1080/13554790008402767}}</ref>
==Signs and symptoms==
Deep dyslexia is mainly characterized by the occurrence of [[Semantics|semantic]] reading errors or semantic [[paralexias]] (transposition of letters or words) when reading aloud (e.g. the written word "view" is read aloud as "scene", the word "bird" is read as "canary").<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Plaut">{{cite journal|last=Plaut|first=David C.|author2=Shallice, Tim|title=Deep dyslexia: A case study of connectionist neuropsychology|journal=Cognitive Neuropsychology|year=1993|volume=10|issue=5|pages=377–500|doi=10.1080/02643299308253469}}</ref><ref name= "Weekes">{{cite journal|last=Weekes|first=Brendan|author2=Coltheart, Max |author3=Gordon, Evian |title=Deep dyslexia and right hemisphere reading-a regional cerebral blood flow study|journal=Aphasiology|year=1997|volume=11|issue=12|pages=1139–1158|doi=10.1080/02687039708249437}}</ref> These semantic errors are the major distinguishing feature of deep dyslexia in comparison to other central dyslexias.<ref name= "Coslett" /> There are many other symptoms of deep dyslexia, including visual errors (e.g. the written word "thing" is read aloud as "think", the word "skate" is read as "scale") and derivational errors (e.g. the written word "alcohol" is read aloud as "alcoholic", the word "governor" is read as "government"), and poor reading of [[function word]]s.<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Plaut" /><ref name= "Weekes" /> Additionally, deep dyslexics have more difficulty reading [[Abstract and concrete|abstract]] than [[Abstract and concrete|concrete]] and highly imaginable words, more difficulty reading [[adjective]]s, [[adverb]]s, and [[verb]]s than [[noun]]s, a complete inability to read [[Pseudoword|non-words]], and often impairments on tasks of verbal [[working memory]].<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Plaut" /><ref name= "Weekes" /><ref name= "Harley book">{{cite book|last=Harley|first=Trevor|title=The psychology of language : from data to theory|year=2005|publisher=Psychology Press|location=Hove|isbn=978-0-86377-867-4|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Kolb|first=Bryan|title=Fundamentals of human neuropsychology|year=2008|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|location=Basingstoke|isbn=0-7167-9586-8|edition=6th|author2=Whishaw, Ian Q.}}</ref>
While the symptoms of deep dyslexia listed above are different and independent impairments of reading, it is rare to find an individual who only displays some of the characteristics of it; indeed, most patients presenting with semantic paralexias, a hallmark symptom of the disorder, also demonstrate all of the other symptoms.<ref name= "Weekes" /><ref name= "Coltheartmax">{{cite book|last=Coltheart|first=Edited by Max|title=*Deep dyslexia.|year=1980|publisher=Routhledge & Kegan Paul|location=London|isbn=0-7100-0456-7|edition=[1st publ.].|author2=Patterson, Karalyn |author3=Marshall, John C. }}</ref> This has resulted in deep dyslexia being considered a symptom-complex and has led to much research into why this variety of symptoms may co-occur in so many patients.<ref name= "Weekes" /><ref name= "Coltheartmax" />
===Imageability effect and ease of predication===
The difficulty of deep dyslexics in reading abstract words has been referred to as the "[[imageability]] effect".<ref name= "Temple" /><ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Jones">{{cite journal|last=Jones|first=GV|title=Deep dyslexia, imageability, and ease of predication.|journal=Brain and Language|year=1985|volume=24|issue=1|pages=1–19|pmid=3971130|doi=10.1016/0093-934x(85)90094-x}}</ref><ref name= "Riley">{{cite journal|last=Riley|first=EA|author2=Thompson, CK|title=Semantic Typicality Effects in Acquired Dyslexia: Evidence for Semantic Impairment in Deep Dyslexia.|journal=Aphasiology|year=2010|volume=24|issue=6–8|pages=802–813|pmid=20657815|doi=10.1080/02687030903422486|pmc=2907924}}</ref> According to this idea, the ease with which a [[mental image]] can be created for a word is strongly related to the ease of reading the word.<ref name= "Jones" /> In an attempt to explain this relationship, researchers have developed a variable to link the mental imagery created by a word and the ease of reading it.<ref name= "Jones" /> This variable, [[ease of predication]], is a rating of how easy it is to come up with simple factual statements or attributes of a word.<ref name= "Jones" /><ref name= "Harley2">{{cite journal|last=Harley|first=Trevor A.|title=Connectionist approaches to language disorders|journal=Aphasiology|year=1993|volume=7|issue=3|pages=221–249|doi=10.1080/02687039308249508}}</ref> For example, when presented with the word "dog", an individual may come up with statements, or [[Predicate (grammar)|predicates]], such as "has four legs", "is an animal", or "barks and wags its tail". Words with higher ease of predication scores are more easily read aloud by deep dyslexics than words with lower ease of predicaton scores, yet there is no correlation between ease of predication and ease of reading seen in normal adult readers.<ref name= "Jones" /><ref name= "Harley2" /> Ease of predication may not explain specific symptoms of deep dyslexia, but rather indicates that deep dyslexics read using imagery, or a predicational route, rather than the more precise mechanisms used in normal reading.<ref name= "Jones" />
==Mechanism==
There are many different, and often conflicting, hypotheses that attempt to explain the deficits associated with deep dyslexia.<ref name= "Shallice">{{cite book|last=Shallice|first=Tim|title=From neuropsychology to mental structure|year=1988|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge [England]|isbn=0521308747|edition=Reprint.}}</ref> These theories have resulted in several models designed to conceptualize the symptom-complex found in deep dyslexics. These models are not ordered chronologically, but rather follow a general increasing trend of presence in the field of knowledge regarding deep dyslexics. Some models may be stronger than others, but that is not necessarily reflected here. Models and hypothesis toward the end of the list are more heavily debated and thus typically have a greater wealth of knowledge surrounding their topic.<ref name = "Colangelo" />
===Continuum model===
The "Glosser and Friedman (continuum) model" is based upon the concept that deep dyslexia and phonological dyslexia are opposite endpoints on a "continuum" of reading disability.<ref name= "Colangelo" /><ref name= "Friedman">{{cite journal|last=Friedman|first=Rhonda B.|title=Recovery from Deep Alexia to Phonological Alexia: Points on a Continuum|journal=Brain and Language|year=1996|volume=52|issue=1|pages=114–128|doi=10.1006/brln.1996.0006}}<!--|accessdate=18 March 2013--></ref> Deep dyslexia appears to be a more severe form of phonological dyslexia;<ref name= "Rapcsak" /><ref name= "Orden" /><ref name= "Lambon" /> however, symptoms in patients can change over time so that an initial diagnosis of deep dyslexia is later better described as strictly a phonological dyslexia.<ref name= "Colangelo" /> These observations suggest recovery is possible along the [[semantic pathway]].<ref name= "Colangelo" />
Friedman justifies the continuum hypothesis with two sets of evidence. The first involves five patients who started with deep dyslexia, but whose disorders shifted to phonological dyslexia during recovery. Semantic paralexias were the first symptom to diminish, either partially or totally, in each case and then other symptoms were resolved to varying degrees after that. However, nonword reading was always the last symptom to go and complete recovery was never reached by any patient.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Crisp|first=J.|last2=Ralph|first2=M.A.|date=|year=2006|others=|title=Unlocking the Nature of the Phonological-Deep Dyslexia Continuum: The Keys to Reading Aloud Are in Phonology and Semantics|url=|journal=Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience|volume=18|issue=3|pages=348–362|doi=10.1162/089892906775990543|pmid=16513001|access-date=}}</ref>
Her second set of evidence in support of the continuum was found in her review of eleven patients with deep or phonological dyslexia in whom she found a predictable succession of symptoms. She placed great emphasis on the order in which reading symptoms emerged (poor nonword reading first, then visual errors, then noun > functor, then noun > verb, concrete > abstract, and finally, semantic errors) and suggested that the continuum hypothesis was supported by this pattern of symptoms.<ref name=":0" />
===Connectionist model===
[[File:Connectionist model of deep dyslexia.png|thumb|right|300px|Deep dyslexics have sufficient activation of a written word's features; but, this activation decays quickly, leading to errors in speech output.]] The "connectionist model" suggests that the phonological and semantic features of a word are [[Spreading activation|activated]], but this activation decays at a rate too quick for cognitive processing- thus, errors in speech output are produced as a result of this fading activation.<ref name= "Colangelo" /><ref name= "Buchanan" /> This hypothesis explains the broad symptom-complex of deep dyslexics without resorting to a multiple loci damage approach as seen in other models.<ref name= "Colangelo" /><ref name= "Buchanan" /> It eliminates the need to attribute a specific locus of damage to each symptom of deep dylsexia, and instead states that all symptoms are due to decay of a large activation area.<ref name= "Colangelo" /><ref name= "Buchanan" />
=== Distributed attractor networks === Plaut and Shallice have hypothesized that units in the brain interact in such a way that semantic features form stable attractors in the space of all possible representations of words. These unit interactions correspond to particular attractor patterns, and if the particular attractor pattern is activated, the network remains in that pattern. However, they hypothesize that when the pattern is distorted, there is a pull on the pattern, and it gravitates toward the correct pattern, almost as if this semantic space is filled with basins, where if one point on the pattern falls to the edge of the basin, it will still gravitate toward the middle. If you lesion this area, the neurons die and the basins change their shape. When this happens, you may now have the same distorted starting pattern that will end up in a neighboring basin, which is a semantically related area, but not the correct one, and this would account for deep dyslexic patients to incorrectly identify "river" as "ocean". Lesions that occur early in the network change the basins that send different semantic words to different areas of the network, whereas if they occur later, the words will be much closer semantically. This may account for severity of the deficit in individual patients.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Plaut|first=D.C.|date=|year=1995|title=Double Dissociation Without Modularity: Evidence from Connectionist Neuropsychology|url=|journal=Journal of Clinical and Experimental Neuropsychology|volume=17|issue=2|pages=291–321|doi=10.1080/01688639508405124|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
===Failure of inhibition hypothesis===
The "failure of inhibition hypothesis" states that the presentation of a target word activates [[semantic memory]] of that word, along with memory for other words that are semantically related.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> For example, the target word "dog" may activate "bark", "cat", "squirrel", "ball", "fetch". Deep dyslexic patients are unable to inhibit the other related words, so they are likely to substitute one of these words for the target word in speech production (explicit output).<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> This hypothesis contradicts the belief of other researchers that the deficits seen in deep dyslexics are due to [[Mental process|processing]] problems.
Researchers believe that "failure of inhibition" has no effect on [[Implicit learning|implicit]] processing, but instead is the cause of impairments in the explicit task of speech production.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> They believe that explicit characteristics of reading involve only the conscious production of speech (reading).<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> Information about written words is internalized without awareness (implicitly); the ability to access this information and process it into words that can be read or spoken is an explicit process. Implicit knowledge involves [[phonological awareness]], understanding of the [[Morphology (linguistics)|morphology]], and a semantic understanding of written words.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> This implicit aspect of reading may be completely intact, and yet reading errors can still occur through defects in explicit output, or production.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> Researchers have studied the dissociation of implicit and explicit processes to thus unravel the underlying deficiencies in deep dyslexia. Studies in support of "failure of inhibition" show intact implicit processing of deep dyslexics.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> For instance, studies have shown deep dyslexics that are equally fast in a [[lexical decision task]] with a rhyming pair of words (book-took) in comparison to a non-rhyming pair of words (bough-tough), indicating that the patients are able to use implicit phonological knowledge and [[phonics]] to process the words.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> Additionally, they are faster in a lexical decision task with words that sound like they are spelled (couch, pouch) than they are with words that do not sound like they are spelled (touch), again showing that patients are using phonology.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> These data show that implicit processing is in fact occurring in deep dyslexic patients. Thus, some researchers believe that the impairments present in deep dyslexics are only in explicit phonological output (i.e., reading aloud).<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> They believe that the problems of deep dyslexics are due to production errors, and that deep dyslexics have normal phonological processing at the implicit level.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /> This is supported by the fact that deep dyslexia is often present in patients suffering from production errors resulting from [[Expressive aphasia]].<ref name= "Lambon" />
Riley and Thompson expanded on this theory in 2010. Previous studies had shown that typical in patients with deep dyslexia, typical members of a semantic category (like "robin" in the category of "birds") are processed faster than atypical members of the same category (like "ostrich"), known as the semantic typicality effect. According to their research, this typicality effect may indicate an inability to efficiently select a correct lexical-semantic representation. They suggest that selection inhibition becomes impaired beginning at the level of semantics rather than the later levels of production like the original failure of inhibition hypothesis suggests.<ref name="Riley" />
===Dual route model===
[[File:Dual route model and deep dyslexia diagram.svg|thumb|right|300px|Deep dyslexia can affect both pathways in the dual-route hypothesis of reading.]] {{main article|Dual-route hypothesis to reading aloud}} The "Morton and Patterson (dual route) model" is based upon the [[Dual-route hypothesis to reading aloud|dual route hypothesis of reading]]. It proposes that the occurrence of semantic errors alongside an inability to read non-words aloud must be due to multiple loci of damage within this dual-route model.<ref name= "Colangelo" /> Because a deep dyslexic cannot read aloud non-words, a disruption in the [[Phonology|phonological]] process is assumed, forcing reading to proceed through the semantic route.<ref name= "Colangelo" /> However, deep dyslexics also produce semantic errors while reading, alluding to damage in this pathway as well.<ref name= "Colangelo" /> Other researchers refer to the phonological and semantic route as "modules".<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /><ref name= "Orden" /> They believe that patients have a partially functioning [[Lexicon|lexical]] module and a completely deficient nonlexical module.<ref name= "Orden" /> The lexical module is analogous to the semantic route in the dual route model and relies on lexical memory, or the memory for words, to name words.<ref name= "Colangelokaren" /><ref name= "Orden" /> In using the lexical module, an individual accesses a "mental dictionary" of words. The nonlexical module is comparable to the phonological route and uses knowledge of spelling and [[grapheme]]s to create [[phoneme]]s to name words and nonwords.<ref name= "Orden" /> The absent nonlexical module in deep dyslexics explains why patients cannot name nonwords.<ref name= "Orden" />
===Right and left hemisphere hypotheses=== [[File:HearReadBrain.png|thumb|Activation areas in the left hemisphere when hearing or reading a word. The "left-hemisphere hypothesis", supports the idea of a damaged left hemisphere-based reading system.]]
Normal reading is typically a function of a left [[Lateralization of brain function|hemisphere-based system]].<ref name= "Coslett" /> The right [[Cerebral hemisphere|hemisphere]] plays a minimal role in reading.<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Shallice" /> One hypothesis, the "left hemisphere hypothesis", supports the idea of a damaged left hemisphere-based reading system associated with deep dyslexia.<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Coltheart">{{cite journal|last=Coltheart|first=Max|title=Deep Dyslexia Is Right-Hemisphere Reading|journal=Brain and Language|year=2000|volume=71|issue=2|pages=299–309|doi=10.1006/brln.1999.2183}}</ref><ref name= "Salmelin">{{cite journal|last=Salmelin|first=R|author2=Helenius, P |author3=Service, E |title=Neurophysiology of fluent and impaired reading: a magnetoencephalographic approach.|journal=Journal of Clinical Neurophysiology|year=2000|volume=17|issue=2|pages=163–74|pmid=10831107|doi=10.1097/00004691-200003000-00005}}</ref> Deep dyslexics may be attempting to use this damaged left hemisphere, resulting in severe reading deficits.<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Coltheart" /><ref name= "Salmelin" /><ref>{{cite book|last=Warrington|first=Rosaleen A. McCarthy, Elizabeth K.|title=Cognitive neuropsychology : a clinical introduction|year=1990|publisher=Academic Press|location=San Diego|isbn=0124818463|edition=[7. Nachdr.]}}</ref> On the other hand, the "right hemisphere hypothesis" states that deep dyslexics attempt to read using a completely different reading system.<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Shallice" /><ref name= "Coltheart" /> According to this hypothesis, they are using the right hemisphere for [[Orthography|orthographic]] and semantic processing, but given that this system does not usually play a role in reading, deep dyslexics have many reading disabilities.<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Coltheart" /> Strong support for this hypothesis comes from studies of [[split-brain]] patients who use the right hemisphere for reading. These patients makes semantic errors similar to those seen with deep dyslexia.<ref>{{cite book|last=Shallice|first=Tim|title=From neuropsychology to mental structure|year=1988|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page= 112|location=Cambridge [England]|isbn=0521308747|edition=Reprint.}}</ref> Numerous studies have shown that the right hemisphere ''can'' contribute to reading when a patient's left hemisphere is damaged.<ref name= "Coslett" /><ref name= "Shallice" /> Brain imaging studies, performed both on deep dyslexics and in other patients with left hemisphere injury, have shown that the damaged left hemisphere is still playing a role in reading.<ref name= "Coltheart" /><ref name= "Salmelin" /> However, the imaging has also shown that areas of the right hemisphere are also active during reading.<ref name= "Coltheart" /><ref name= "Salmelin" /> Thus, it currently appears that there is greater support in favor of the right-hemisphere hypothesis.<ref name = "Coltheart" />
==Treatment== There have been many different studies done in an attempt to treat deep dyslexics, all which have been met with varying success. One method that has been frequently used is to teach patients to sound out words using grapheme-to-phoneme correspondence rules (for example, using single letter graphemes such as the letter 'B" to link with larger words such as "Baby", allowing for association of phonemes).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Friedman|first=Rhonda B.|author2=Lott, Susan Nitzberg|title=Successful blending in a phonological reading treatment for deep alexia|journal=Aphasiology|year=2002|volume=16|issue=3|pages=355–372|doi=10.1080/02687040143000627}}</ref> Such methods are known as "non-lexically based reading treatments". Other studies have looked at attempting to repair the semantic-lexical route, known as "lexically based treatment".<ref name= "Rilling">{{cite journal|last=Stadie|first=Nicole|author2=Rilling, Eva|title=Evaluation of lexically and nonlexically based reading treatment in a deep dyslexic|journal=Cognitive Neuropsychology|year=2006|volume=23|issue=4|pages=643–672|doi=10.1080/02643290500538364}}<!--|accessdate=16 March 2013--></ref> Regardless of the methodology, treatment studies with deep dyslexics are difficult because much of the information regarding this disability is still heavily debated.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} Treatment options may be successful on repairing one route of reading but not another, and success for one patient may not translate to success in another.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}}

The '''Carlo F. Dondena Centre for Research on Social Dynamics''' was established at [[Bocconi University]] in 2006. It aims to promote, coordinate and conduct interdisciplinary [[research]] on [[social dynamics]], with emphasis on medium- and long-term processes and on comparative analysis.
The main areas of interest of the Centre are [[demography]] and the life course, e.g., fertility and family dynamics, intergenerational relationships and ageing, transitions to adulthood, migration, lifelong learning, social networks, medium- and long-range forecasting, labour market and [[social mobility]]; development and social cohesion, e.g., inequality, social norms and economic development, polarization, integration of migrants and second generations; welfare state and public policies, e.g. social policies in comparative perspective, [[Europeanisation]] and regional issues; and [[data]] collection and harmonisation, including creation of a data archive.
Researchers involved in the Centre include [[Demography|demographers]], [[economists]], experts in [[law]], [[Political science|political scientists]], social [[psychologists]], and [[statisticians]].

'''Eighteenth Century Collections Online''' ('''ECCO''') is a [[digital collection]] of books published in [[Great Britain]] during the 18th century.<ref name="navguide">{{Cite web |url=http://www.gale.cengage.com/pdf/navguide/ECCO_nvg.pdf |title=ECCO Navigation Guide |format=PDF |accessdate=11 January 2014}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated2">{{Cite web |url=http://www.jisc.ac.uk/Home/news/stories/2009/06/ecco.aspx |title=JISC: The world’s largest digital library of 18th century printed books grows even larger for UK academic community |accessdate=11 January 2014}}</ref>
[[Gale (publisher)|Gale]], an education publishing company in the United States, assembled the collection by [[Film scanner|digitally scanning]] [[microfilm]] reproductions of 136,291 titles.<ref name="navguide"/><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Smith |first=Jennette |date=18 August 2003 |title=Gale, ProQuest hope to find new money in old documents: Gale Group launches new Eighteenth Century Collections Online |journal=[[Crain's Detroit Business]] |quote='The microfilm images are digitized using software developed by HTC Global Services in Troy. The cost per image has declined from 16–19 cents to below double digits' said CEO Allen Paschal.}}</ref> Documents scanned after 2002 are added to a second collection, ECCO II. As of January 2014, ECCO II comprises 46,607 titles.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gale.cengage.co.uk/product-highlights/history/eighteenth-century-collections-online.aspx |title=ECCO Part II: New Editions |website=Gale / Cengage Learning |publisher=Cengage Learning |accessdate=11 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111134911/http://gale.cengage.co.uk/product-highlights/history/eighteenth-century-collections-online.aspx |archivedate=11 January 2014 |df= }}</ref>
==Conversions and access== So far 2,231 texts have been released free to the public<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.18thconnect.org/news/?p=49 |title=TCP and Gale Cengage release 2,200 ECCO Texts to the public |publisher=18thconnect.org |date=2011-04-25 |accessdate=2013-01-19}}</ref> through the work of the [[University of Michigan]]’s [[Text Creation Partnership]]. Rather than [[Optical character recognition|OCR]], they [[rekey]] the texts<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.umich.edu/tcp/ecco/description.html |title=Text Creation Partnership - Transcribed by hand. Owned by libraries. Made for everyone |publisher=Lib.umich.edu |date= |accessdate=2013-01-19}}</ref> and tag them with [[Text Encoding Initiative|TEI]].<ref name="umich1">{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.umich.edu/tcp/about/about.html |title=Text Creation Partnership - Transcribed by hand. Owned by libraries. Made for everyone |publisher=Lib.umich.edu |date= |accessdate=2013-01-19}}</ref> Their aim is to enable improved access to a fraction of the collection: they are making [[SGML]]/[[XML]] text editions for 10,000 books.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/text-idx?cc=ecco&page=bib&c=ecco |title=Eighteenth Century Collections Online |publisher=Quod.lib.umich.edu |date= |accessdate=2013-01-19}}</ref> In addition to the free version, subscription access is also offered.<ref name="umich1"/>
Text analytic tools are available on this subset through the [[Text Analysis Portal for Research]] project.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://portal.tapor.ca/news-feeds/2.rss/440 |title=TAPoR News Channel: General |publisher=Portal.tapor.ca |date=2011-04-29 |accessdate=2013-01-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120517132526/http://portal.tapor.ca/news-feeds/2.rss/440 |archivedate=2012-05-17 |df= }}</ref>
One of the "Text Creation Partners", the [[University of Oxford]], has converted the public domain texts into free, publicly accessible versions, in accordance with the [[Text Encoding Initiative]] P5 guidelines, and makes them available in a variety of [[file format]]s, including HTML and [[EPUB]] via the [[Oxford Text Archive]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tei.oucs.ox.ac.uk/ecco/ |title=Oxford conversion of ECCO |publisher=Tei.oucs.ox.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-01-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120430012717/http://tei.oucs.ox.ac.uk/ecco/ |archivedate=2012-04-30 |df= }}</ref>
Cross-search is also available from [[ProQuest]] for those who subscribe to both [[Early English Books Online]] and ECCO.<ref>ProQuest offers ProQuest announced an agreement with Gale, part of Cengage Learning, to connect its respective digital research databases of early modern English books via cross-search technology. [[Online]] January 1, 2008.</ref>

{{More references|date=December 2009}} '''European studies''' is a field of study offered by many academic [[college]]s and [[university|universities]] that focuses on current developments in [[European integration]].
Some programmes offer a social science or public administration curriculum focusing on developments in the European Union. These programmes usually include a combination of political science, EU public policy, [[European history]], [[European law]], [[economics]] and [[sociology]]. Other universities approach the subject in a broader manner, including topics like [[European culture]], [[European literature]] and [[European languages]]. While all programmes focus on the study of the European Union, they often cover national topics (in a comparative perspective) as well.
The subject combines [[humanities]] and [[social sciences]]. Disciplines that are involved in European studies include:
[[File:Diploma-licenciatura-estudos-europeus-universidade.jpg|thumb|The [[Bachelor's degree]] in [[European Studies]] from ''[[Universidade Aberta]]'' is [[interdisciplinarity|interdisciplinary]] and offers different [[Minor_(academic)|Minors]], namely in [[Economics]], [[Law]] and [[Sociology]]<ref>https://www2.uab.pt/guiainformativo/eng_detailcursos.php?curso=14v</ref>]]
{{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Anthropology]] * [[Cultural studies]] * [[Economics]] * [[European languages]] * [[Geography]] * [[History]] * [[International relations]] * [[Law]] * [[Linguistics]] * [[Literature]] * [[Philosophy]] * [[Psychology]] * [[Political science]] * [[Public administration]] * [[Sociology]] }}
While European studies departments are obviously more common in Europe than elsewhere, there are departments dedicated to its study further afield, including in [[North America]], [[Asia]] and [[Australasia]].
== European studies associations == * [[UACES]] - the academic association for Contemporary European Studies * [[European Union Studies Association]] * [[Arbeitskreis Europäische Integration]]

{{Redirect2|Game world|In-universe|Game-based worlds|Virtual world|the template|Template:in-universe|information about "in-universe" in a Wikipedian perspective|WP:INUNIVERSE}} {{Further|Planets in science fiction|Fantasy world|List of fictional location types}} {{Multiple issues| {{more footnotes|date=June 2012}} {{tone|date=August 2015}} {{original research|date=August 2015}} }} [[File:Map-of-Oz.jpg|thumb|300px|Map of the [[land of Oz]], the fictional realm that is the setting for [[L. Frank Baum]]'s "[[List of Oz books|Oz]]" series.]] A '''fictional universe''' is a [[consistency|self-consistent]] [[setting (narrative)|setting]] with events, and often other elements, that differ from the real world. It may also be called an imagined, constructed or fictional realm (or world). Fictional universes may appear in [[novel]]s, [[comics]], [[film]]s, [[Television program|television shows]], [[video game]]s, and other creative works.
A fictional universe can be almost indistinguishable from the real world, except for the presence of the invented [[character (arts)|character]]s and events that characterize a work of fiction; at the other extreme, it can bear little or no resemblance to the real world, with invented fundamental principles of time and space.
The subject is most commonly addressed in reference to fictional universes that differ markedly from the real world, such as those that introduce entire fictional cities, countries, or even planets, or those that contradict commonly known facts about the world and its history, or those that feature fantasy or [[science fiction]] concepts such as [[Magic in fiction|magic]] or [[faster than light]] travel—and especially those in which the deliberate development of the setting is a substantial focus of the work.
==Definition== What distinguishes a fictional universe from a simple setting is the level of detail and internal consistency. A fictional universe has an established continuity and internal logic that must be adhered to throughout the work and even across separate works. So, for instance, many books may be set in conflicting fictional versions of [[Victorian London]], but all the stories of [[Sherlock Holmes]] are set in ''the same'' Victorian London. However, the [[Adaptations of Sherlock Holmes|various film series based on Sherlock Holmes]] follow their own separate continuities, thus not taking place in the same fictional universe.
The history and geography of a fictional universe are well defined, and maps and timelines are often included in works set within them. Even new [[fictional language|languages]] may be constructed. When subsequent works are written within the same universe, care is usually taken to ensure that established facts of the [[canon (fiction)|canon]] are not violated. Even if the fictional universe involves concepts such as elements of magic that don't exist in the real world, these must adhere to a set of rules established by the author.
A famous example of a detailed fictional universe is [[Arda (Middle-earth)|Arda]] (more popularly known as [[Middle-earth]]), of [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]'s books ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' and ''[[The Silmarillion]]''. He created first its [[Languages of Arda|languages]] and then the world itself, which he states was "primarily linguistic in inspiration and was begun in order to provide the necessary 'history' for the Elvish tongues."<ref>Foreword to ''[[The Fellowship of the Ring]]'', by J.R.R. Tolkien</ref>
A modern example of a [[Fictional universe of Avatar|fictional universe]] is that of the ''[[Avatar (2009 film)|Avatar]]'' film series, as [[James Cameron]] has invented an entire [[Pandoran biosphere|ecosystem]], with a team of scientists to test whether it was viable. Additionally, he commissioned a linguistics expert to invent the [[Na'vi language|''Na'vi'' language]].
Virtually every successful fictional [[TV series]] or [[comic book]] develops its own "universe" to keep track of the various episodes or issues. Writers for that series must follow the ''[[Bible (writing)|story bible]]'',<ref name="jane">[http://www.janeespenson.com/archives/00000550.php How to Give Maris Hives, Alphabetized] (April 2008), a blog entry by scriptwriter [[Jane Espenson]]</ref> which often becomes the series canon.
Frequently, when a series is perceived by its creators as too complicated or too self-inconsistent (because of, for example, too many writers), the producers or publishers may introduce [[retroactive continuity]] (retcon) to make future editions easier to write and more consistent. This creates an alternate universe that future authors can write about. These stories about the universe or universes that existed before the retcon are usually not canonical, unless the franchise-holder gives permission. ''[[Crisis on Infinite Earths]]'' was an especially sweeping example.
Some writers choose to introduce elements or characters from one work into another, to present the idea that both works are set in the same universe. For example, the character of [[Ursula Buffay]] from American [[sitcom]] ''[[Mad About You]]'' was also a recurring guest star in ''[[Friends]]'', despite the two series having little else in common. Fellow NBC series ''[[Seinfeld]]'' also contained [[Fictional crossover|crossover]] references to ''Mad About You''. [[L. Frank Baum]] introduced the characters of [[Cap'n Bill]] and [[Trot (Oz)|Trot]] (from ''[[The Sea Fairies]]'') into the Oz series in ''[[The Scarecrow of Oz]]'', and they made a number of appearances in later Oz books. In science fiction, [[A. Bertram Chandler]] introduced into his future Galactic civilization the character [[Dominic Flandry]] from [[Poul Anderson]]'s quite different Galactic future (he had Anderson's consent) – on the assumption that these were two [[alternate history]] timelines and that people could on some occasions cross from one to the other.
==Scope== [[Sir Thomas More]]'s ''[[Utopia (book)|Utopia]]'' is one of the earliest examples of a cohesive fictional world with its own rules and functional concepts, but it comprises only one small island. Later fictional universes, like [[Robert E. Howard]]'s ''[[Conan the Barbarian|Conan the Cimmerian]]'' stories or [[Lev Grossman]]'s [[Fillory]], are global in scope and some, like ''[[Star Wars]]'', ''[[Honorverse]]'', ''[[BattleTech]]'', or the [[Lensman series]], are galactic or even intergalactic.
A fictional universe may even concern itself with more than one interconnected universe through fictional devices such as dreams, "[[time travel]]" or "parallel worlds". Such a series of interconnected universes is often called a [[parallel universe (fiction)|multiverse]]. Such multiverses have been featured prominently in science fiction since at least the mid-20th century.
The classic ''[[Star Trek: The Original Series|Star Trek]]'' episode "[[Mirror, Mirror (Star Trek: The Original Series)|Mirror, Mirror]]" introduced the [[Mirror Universe (Star Trek)|Mirror Universe]], in which the crew members of the [[Starship Enterprise|Starship ''Enterprise'']] were brutal rather than compassionate. The 2009 movie ''[[Star Trek (film)|Star Trek]]'' created an "alternate reality" and freed the ''[[Star Trek]]'' [[media franchise|franchise]] from [[continuity (fiction)|continuity]] issues. In the mid-1980s, [[DC Comics]] ''[[Crisis on Infinite Earths]]'' streamlined its fictional continuity by destroying most of its alternate universes.
==Format== A fictional universe can be contained in a single work, as in [[George Orwell]]'s ''[[Nineteen Eighty-Four]]'' or [[Aldous Huxley]]'s ''[[Brave New World]]'', or in [[serial (literature)|serial]]ized, [[book series|series]]-based, open-ended or [[Round-robin story|round robin]]-style fiction.
In most small-scale fictional universes, general properties and [[timeline]] events fit into a consistently organized [[continuity (fiction)|continuity]]. However, in the case of universes that are rewritten or revised by different [[writer]]s, [[editing|editors]], or [[Film producers|producer]]s, this continuity may be violated, by accident or by design.
The occasional publishing use of retroactive continuity ([[retcon]]) often occurs due to this kind of revision or oversight. Members of [[fandom]] often create a kind of [[fan-made]] canon ([[canon (fiction)#Nature of fictional canons|fanon]]) to patch up such errors; "fanon" that becomes generally accepted sometimes becomes actual canon. Other fan-made additions to a universe ([[fan fiction]], [[parallel universe (fiction)|alternate universe]], [[pastiche]], [[parody]]) are usually not considered canonical unless they get [[authorization|authorized]].
==Collaboration== {{see also|Shared universe}}
Shared universes often come about when a fictional universe achieves great commercial success and attracts other media. For example, a successful movie may catch the attention of various book authors, who wish to write stories based on that movie. Under U.S. law, the copyright-holder retains control of all other [[derivative work]]s, including those written by other authors, but they might not feel comfortable in those other mediums or may feel that other individuals will do a better job; therefore, they may open up the copyright on a shared-universe basis. The degree to which the copyright-holder or [[franchise (media)|franchise]] retains control is often one of the points in the [[license agreement#Intellectual property|license agreement]].
For example, the comic book ''[[Superman (comic book)|Superman]]'' was so popular that it spawned over 30 different radio, television, and movie series and a similar number of [[video game]]s, as well as theme park rides, books, and songs. In the other direction, both ''Star Trek'' and ''Star Wars'' are responsible for hundreds of books and games of varying levels of canonicity.
Fictional universes are sometimes shared by multiple prose authors, with each author's works in that universe being granted approximately equal canonical status. For example, [[Larry Niven]]'s fictional universe [[Known Space]] has an approximately 135-year period in which Niven allows other authors to write stories about the [[Man-Kzin Wars]]. Other fictional universes, like the [[Ring of Fire series|''Ring of Fire'' series]], actively court canonical [[The Grantville Gazettes|stimulus from fans]], but gate and control the changes through a formalized process and the final say of [[Eric Flint|the editor and universe creator]].<ref>{{cite book | title =''[[Grantville Gazette III]]'' | others = [[Thomas Kidd (illustrator)|Thomas Kidd]] (cover art) | ISBN = 978-1-4165-0941-7 |id={{ISBN|1-4165-0941-0}} | publisher = [[Baen Books]] | last = [[Eric Flint|Flint, Eric]] and various others | pages = 311–313|quote=The print published and e-published Grantville Gazettes all contain a post book [[afterword]] detailing where and how to submit a manuscript to the fictional canon oversight process for the [[1632 series]].}}</ref>
Other universes are created by one or several authors but are intended to be used non-canonically by others, such as the fictional settings for [[game]]s, particularly [[role-playing game]]s and video games. Settings for the role-playing game ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' are called [[campaign setting]]s; other games have also incorporated this term on occasion. [[Virtual world]]s are fictional worlds in which [[online]] computer games, notably [[MMORPG]]s and [[MUD]]s, take place. A [[fictional crossover]] occurs when two or more [[fictional character]]s, series or universes cross over with one another, usually in the context of a character created by one author or owned by one [[company (law)|company]] meeting a character created or owned by another. In the case where two fictional universes covering entire ''actual'' universes cross over, physical travel from one universe to another may actually occur in the course of the story. Such crossovers are usually, but not always, considered non-canonical by their creators or by those in charge of the [[intellectual property|properties]] involved.
==Lists of fictional universes==
For lists of fictional universes see:
*[[List of fictional shared universes in film and television]] *[[List of fictional universes in animation and comics]] *[[List of fictional universes in literature]] *[[List of science fiction universes]]
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Alternate history (fiction)|Alternate history]] * [[Alternate universe (fan fiction)]] * [[Constructed world]] * [[Continuity (fiction)]] * [[Diegesis]] * [[Expanded universe]] * [[Shared universe]] * [[Fantasy world]] * [[Fictional country]] * [[Fictional location]] * [[Future history]] * [[Index of fictional places]] * [[List of fantasy worlds]] * [[Mythical place]] * [[Paracosm]] * [[Parallel universe (fiction)|Parallel universe]] * [[Planets in science fiction]] * [[Setting (fiction)]] * [[Simulated reality]] * [[Virtual reality]] *[[Multiverse#Multiverse Hypothesis in fiction|Multiverse]] {{div col end}}

'''Forensic art''' is any [[art]] used in [[Law enforcement agency|law enforcement]] or [[legal process|legal proceedings]]. Forensic art is used to assist law enforcement with the visual aspects of a case, often using witness descriptions and video footage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://forensicfaces.weebly.com/what-is-forensic-art.html|title=What is Forensic Art? - Forensic Faces Institute|website=forensicfaces.weebly.com|access-date=2017-11-06}}</ref>
It is a highly specialised field that covers a wide range of artistic skills, such as [[Facial composite|composite drawing]], crime scene sketching, [[image modification]] and identification, courtroom drawings, demonstrative evidence, and postmortem and facial approximation aids. It is rare for a forensic artist to specialise in more than one of these skills.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theiai.org/disciplines/art/history.php|title=History of the I.A.I. Forensic Art Discipline|website=www.theiai.org}}</ref> The following is a breakdown of different skills and what they involve: * <u>'''Composite Drawing:'''</u> the main objective is to help investigators generate leads based on physical descriptions. This is usually drawn by hand; an artist who is trained in interviewing victims and witnesses uses the information provided to draw what is described.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forensicmag.com/article/2004/12/forensic-art-defined-and-explained|title=Forensic Art Defined and Explained|date=2004-12-01|work=Forensic Magazine|access-date=2017-11-06}}</ref> Composite art produces a single, graphic image that is designed to be a likeness or similarity of the individual.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.crimesceneinvestigatoredu.org/forensic-artist/|title=Forensic Artist Job Description, Education Requirements and Salary Expectations|website=www.crimesceneinvestigatoredu.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-29}}</ref> * '''<u>Image Modification:</u>''' this is used to change and enhance a photograph in order to help an investigator and/or trial attorney. Examples of this include age progression/regression (see below),<ref name="p1698608879">https://search.proquest.com/docview/1698608879</ref> and the clarifying of images, such as from CCTV footage, to identify an individual.<ref name=":0" /> * '''<u>Image Identification:</u>''' this is the recording a person's distinguishing features for future reference. Investigators can use this tool to identify suspects who attempts to change their appearance to evade capture, as well as in the study of cold cases in which individuals may have changed their appearance since the event.<ref name="p1698608879" /> * '''<u>Crime Scene Sketching:</u>''' the drawing of a crime scene; in the sketch, an investigator includes measurements and dimensions to aid in displaying the layout of the scene. This helps support the information shown in photographs of the scene.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.evidencemagazine.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=184|title=Evidence Technology Magazine – Documenting the Crime Scene|last=MAYO|first=KRISTI|website=www.evidencemagazine.com|access-date=2017-11-06}}</ref> * '''<u>Demonstrative Evidence:</u>''' any visible, physical evidence used in legal proceedings. These are used to demonstrate aspects of the case, reconstruct an event, and illustrate what happened. There are two categories of demonstrative evidence; court displays and investigative aids.<ref name="p1698608879" /> * '''<u>Postmortem Drawing:</u>''' when an artist either looks at a deceased person's photograph or their remains to help identify who the person is and what they looked like prior to their death. This helps most in cases where the body is too damaged by an accident or decomposition.<ref name="p1698608879" /><ref name=":0" /> * '''<u>Age Progression/Regression</u>''': useful to determine what a person's appeearance before or after a period of time. This is most commonly used in missing persons cases or during cold cases when investigators need an idea of what an individual looked like years prior to or following the investigation. * '''<u>Forensic Sculpture</u>''': this is used to create three-dimensional models, usually using the skull of the victims. Other features are added such as fake eyes and wigs to add realism. This process can also inform the investigators of certain characteristics of the victim - such as age, race, and gender - through a detailed knowledge of the intricacies of skeletal structure and other corresponding features such as dental records. It is later photograph and used like postmortem and composite drawings. However, because forensic sculpture relies heavily on assumptions made by the artist, it is not considered a legally recognised technique for positive identification, and is thus used in an advisory capacity only.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Helmer et al. Assessment of the Reliability of Facial Reconstruction|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> * <u>'''Collaboration:'''</u> forensic artists, anthropologists and other professions are used to help determine the age, sex, and race of an identified skull.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://archives.fbi.gov/archives/about-us/lab/forensic-science-communications/fsc/jan2001/taister.htm|title=Book Review of Forensic Art and Illustration (by Taylor), by Taister (Forensic Science Communications, January 2001)|last=Taister|first=Karen T. Taylor, Taylor, Michael A. Taister,|work=FBI|access-date=2017-12-04|language=en-us}}</ref> Many forensic artists do the job as a collateral duty to their "regular" job in law enforcement, such as police officer, crime scene tech, etc. Such forensic artists perform their work while on a fixed salary and are not additionally compensated for artistic duties. There are few full-time forensic artist jobs available. Most full-time artists work in large cities, or in state or federal agencies. "Freelancing" in forensic art is a difficult career path, as ties to law enforcement are a necessary part of the job, and agencies have limited budgets to pay outside contractors.
The skill of '''facial approximation''' is closely associated and related to [[forensic anthropology]] in that an artist specializes in the reconstruction of the remains of a human body. Generally this discipline focuses on the human face for identification purposes. The forensic artist can create a facial approximation in a number of ways to include 2D ([[drawing]]s), 3D ([[sculpture]]s) and other methods using new computer technology. Forensic artists generally can add greater character and make their subjects come back to "life".
== Methods of Manual 3d construction == * Anthropometric was a method developed by [[Wilton M. Krogman]] in 1946 .<ref name="ebscohost.com">{{cite web|url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=110682508&site=ehost-livepose-methods.html|title=What is Anthropometric Measurement? - Tools, Purpose & Methods – Video & Lesson Transcript |website=study.com|access-date=2017-12-05}}</ref> * Facial muscles are recorded by a highly trained professional. This job is particularly tedious, which is why most do not use this method. * Computerized 3d forensic facial reconstruction- manual model clay techniques are used within this method. Computer systems vary, in that some computerized systems used 3D animation software to model the face onto the skull, while other systems use a virtual sculpture system with Haptic feedback<ref name="ebscohost.com" /> * Haptic Feedback- The ability to feel the surface of the skull during analysis and also provide important skeletal details for facial reconstruction such as muscle attachment strength, position of eye, position of malar tubercle etc.<ref name="ebscohost.com" />
== Face model creation == When creating a face model, the forensic artist looks at whether the person is masculine or feminine, as well as their skin tone, age, wrinkles, freckles, the shadow of the beard, and attractiveness. There are three segments that they examine: * Face shape: round, narrow, heart shape, high/low cheeks, high/low chin, double chin, the distance between lips and nose. * Eyes: round, upwards/downwards, the distance of eyeballs, eye color, thin/thick eyebrows, high/low arch brow, distance between both eyebrows, distance between eyebrows and eyes. * Hair: the 3D models have not been programmed to be used with hair, therefore, hair cannot be used the same way as facial attributes. A profile and frontal image of a person is used where 5 to 15 different key features of each hairstyle are selected. These different hairstyles features are from a database used by these professionals. The styles are put into the system where the algorithm automatically estimates the structure of the face. The system is also able to depict different shade of color.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=23414201&site=ehost-live|title=EBSCOhost Login|website=search.ebscohost.com}}</ref>
== Becoming a Forensic Artist == To qualify for a professional certification for forensic arts - such as the Forensic Art Certification, which is provided through the [https://www.theiai.org/certifications/artist/index.php International Association for Identification] - applicants can focus on one or more of the three available categories of professional designation: composite imaging, facial reconstruction, and image enhancement/age progression,<ref name=":0" /> and must: * have at least 80 hours of IAI-approved forensic art training<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.crimesceneinvestigatoredu.org/forensic-artist/|title=Forensic Artist Job Description, Education Requirements and Salary Expectations|website=www.crimesceneinvestigatoredu.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-05}}</ref> * have at least 40 hours of related workshops, lectures, and short program training * have at least 2 years of experience as forensic arts * provide at least 30 forensic art examples that include age progressions, composites, and reconstructions * have a portfolio that demonstrates their forensic art techniques (must include at least 10 forensic art images that were prepared for law enforcement investigation cases)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.crimesceneinvestigatoredu.org/forensic-artist/|title=Forensic Artist Job Description, Education Requirements, and Salary Expectations|website=www.crimesceneinvestigatoredu.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-04}}</ref>

{{Infobox Organization |name = History of Science Society |image = 2007 History of Science Society meeting.jpg |image_border = |size = 300px |caption = Historians of science attending the 2007
international meeting in [[Washington, D.C.]] |map = |msize = |mcaption = |motto = |formation = 1924 |type = Professional Society |headquarters = [[University of Notre Dame]] |location = [[United States]] |membership = |language = |leader_title = President |leader_name = Janet Browne{{cite web|last1=Browne|first1=Janet|title=January 2016 – From the President: Janet Browne|url=http://hssonline.org/resources/publications/newsletter/january-2016-newsletter/january-2016-from-the-president-janet-browne/|website=History of Science Society|accessdate=13 February 2016}} |key_people = Robert Jay Malone (Executive Director) |num_staff = |budget = |website = [http://www.hssonline.org/ www.hssonline.org] }} The '''History of Science Society''' ('''HSS''') is the primary professional society for the academic study of the [[history of science and technology|history of science]]. It was founded in 1924{{cite web|title=History of Science Society|url=https://www.acls.org/societies/societies.aspx?sid=6ba64f5c-c9a2-db11-a735-000c2903e717|website=American Council of Learned Societies|accessdate=13 February 2016}} by [[George Sarton]]{{cite web|title=History of the Society|url=http://hssonline.org/about/history-of-the-society/|website=History of Science Society|accessdate=13 February 2016}} and [[Lawrence Joseph Henderson]],{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Charles H.|title=Henderson, Lawrence Joseph (United States 1878-1942)|url=http://people.wku.edu/charles.smith/chronob/HEND1878.htm|website=Some Biogeographers, Evolutionists and Ecologists: Chrono-Biographical Sketches|accessdate=13 February 2016}} primarily to support the publication of ''[[Isis (journal)|Isis]]'', a journal of the history of science Sarton had started in 1912.{{cite book|last1=Rossiter|first1=Margaret W.|title=Catching Up with the Vision: Essays on the Occasion of the 75th Anniversary of the Founding of the History of Science Society''|date=1999|publisher=University of Chicago Press for the History of Science Society|location=Chicago, Ill.}} The society has over 3,000 members worldwide. It continues to publish the quarterly journal ''Isis,'' the yearly ''[[Osiris (journal)|Osiris]]'', sponsors the IsisCB: History of Science Index,{{cite web|url=http://data.isiscb.org|title=IsisCB Explore|publisher=}} and holds an annual conference. {{As of|2016}}, the current president of the HSS is [[Janet Browne]]. ==Awards and recognition== HSS sponsors two special lectures annually: * The ''George Sarton Memorial Lecture'', delivered at the Annual Meeting of the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] since 1960 (with a break from 1973 to 1975) * The ''History of Science Society Distinguished Lecture'' (formerly the ''History of Science Society Lecture''), delivered at a plenary session of the annual meeting of the HSS since 1981 In addition, the HSS awards a number of prizes: * The [[Suzanne J. Levinson Prize]], established in 2006, is awarded biennially for a book in the history of the life sciences and natural history * The [[Nathan Reingold Prize]] (formerly the Schuman Prize), established in 1955, for an outstanding essay in the history of science written by a graduate student * The [[Derek Price/Rod Webster Prize]] (formerly the Zeitlin-Ver Brugge Prize), established in 1978, for an outstanding article in ''Isis'' * The [[Margaret W. Rossiter History of Women in Science Prize]], first awarded in 1987, for an outstanding work on the subject of women in science (the prize alternates annually between books and journals) * The [[Joseph H. Hazen Education Prize]], established in 1998, for outstanding contributions to teaching history of science * The [[Watson Davis and Helen Miles Davis Prize]], established in 1985, for a textbook or popular book on the history of science * The [[Pfizer Award]], established in 1958, for an outstanding book in the history of science (a medal accompanies this award) * The [[George Sarton Medal]], first awarded in 1955, for lifetime achievement in the history of science == See also == * [[International Academy of the History of Science]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official|http://www.hssonline.org }} *[http://data.isiscb.org IsisCB Explore: History of Science Index] An open access discovery service for the history of science *[http://siarchives.si.edu/collections/siris_arc_229194 History of Science Society, Publications, 1989-1999] from the [[Smithsonian Institution Archives]] {{Presidents of the History of Science Society}} {{University of Notre Dame}} {{Science and technology studies}} {{Midwestern U.S. historical societies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:History Of Science Society}} [[Category:Organizations established in 1924]] [[Category:History of science organizations]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Indiana]] [[Category:Historical societies of the United States]] [[Category:University of Notre Dame]] [[Category:Science and technology studies associations]] [[Category:1924 establishments in the United States]]

The '''Hydropower Sustainability Assessment Protocol''' is a tool that promotes and guides more sustainable [[hydropower]] projects. It is a methodology used to measure the performance of a hydropower project across more than twenty environmental, social, technical and economic topics.
Hydropower projects can have both a positive and a negative environmental and social impact. This is because the construction of a [[dam]], power plant and [[reservoir]] creates certain social and physical changes in the area it effects. The protocol provides a common language to allow governments, [[civil society]], financial institutions and the hydropower sector to talk about and evaluate [[sustainability]] issues.
Assessments are based on objective evidence and the results are presented in a standardised way, to show how new projects are being developed or how existing facilities are performing.
It has been designed to work on projects and facilities anywhere in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hydropower Sustainability - Home|url = http://www.hydrosustainability.org/|website = www.hydrosustainability.org|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Hydropower Sustainability - Protocol Basics|url = http://www.hydrosustainability.org/Protocol.aspx|website = www.hydrosustainability.org|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref>
== Application ==
=== Purpose ===
The Protocol is used by different hydropower stakeholders for different reasons.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hydropower Sustainability - How it can help|url = http://www.hydrosustainability.org/Protocol/How-can-it-help-.aspx|website = www.hydrosustainability.org|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref>
Popular uses include:
* Independent review of sustainability issues * Guiding improvement of sustainability practice * Comparison with international best practice * Communication with stakeholders * Facilitating access to finance * Preparing clients to meet bank requirements * Reducing investment risk
=== Users ===
[[Crédit Agricole]], [[Société Générale|Societe Generale]], [[Standard Chartered]], [[Citigroup|Citi]], and [[UBS]] now refer to the Protocol in their sector guidance.<ref>http://mediacommun.ca-cib.com/sitegenic/medias/DOC/13870/2012-12-politique-sectorielle-rse-energie-hydroelectricite-eng.pdf</ref><ref>http://www.societegenerale.com/sites/default/files/documents/Document%20RSE/Finance%20responsable/Dams%20&%20Hydropower%20Sector%20Policy.pdf</ref><ref>https://www.sc.com/en/resources/global-en/pdf/sustainabilty/Dams_and_Hydropower_Position_Statement.pdf</ref><ref>http://www.citigroup.com/citi/environment/data/1160840_Sector_Brief_HydroPower.pdf</ref><ref>https://www.ubs.com/content/dam/ubs/global/about_ubs/corporate_responsibility/UBS-ESR-framework.pdf</ref>
The [[World Bank]] has analysed the value of the Protocol for use by their clients, concluding that it is a useful tool for guiding the development of sustainable hydropower in developing countries.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Protocol for World Bank clients|url = http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/2014/06/20106007/hydropower-sustainability-assessment-protocol-use-world-bank-clients-lessons-learned-recommendations|website = documents.worldbank.org|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref>
The [[International Institute for Environment and Development]] has reviewed social and environmental safeguards for large dam projects, concluding that the Protocol currently offers the best available ‘measuring stick’ for the [[World Commission on Dams]] provisions.<ref>{{Cite web|title = A review of social and environmental safeguards for large dam projects|url = http://pubs.iied.org/17517IIED.html|website = pubs.iied.org|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref>
=== Process ===
A Protocol assessment takes place over a one-week period at the project site and provides a rapid sustainability check.
A Protocol assessment does not replace an [[Environmental impact assessment|environmental and social impact assessment]] (ESIA), which takes place over a much longer period of time as a mandatory regulatory requirement. A Protocol assessment will, amongst other things, check the scope and quality of the ESIA which has been done.
To ensure high quality, all commercial use of the Protocol is carried out by accredited assessors. These assessors have significant experience of the hydropower sector or relevant sustainability issues, and have passed a rigorous accreditation course.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hydropower Sustainability - Accredited Assessors|url = http://www.hydrosustainability.org/Protocol/Accredited-Assessors.aspx|website = www.hydrosustainability.org|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref>
== Scope ==
=== Tools === The Protocol can be used at any stage of hydropower development, from the early planning stages through to operation. Each project stage is assessed using a different tool: * The early stage tool, a screening tool for potential hydropower projects * The preparation tool, which covers planning and design, management plans and commitments. * The implementation tool, used through the construction phase. * The operation tool, used on working projects.
=== Topics === The Protocol covers a range of topics that need to be understood to assess the overall sustainability of a hydropower project.
The name and range of topics changes slightly at different project stages.
==== Social aspects ====
*Communications and consultation *Project benefits *Project affected communities and livelihoods *Resettlement *[[Indigenous peoples]] *Labour and working conditions *Public health *Cultural heritage
==== Environmental aspects ====
*Environmental and social assessment and management *[[Biodiversity]] and invasive species *[[Erosion]] and [[sedimentation]] *Water quality *Waste, noise and air quality *[[Reservoir]] planning / preparation and filling / management *Downstream flow regimes
==== Business aspects ====
*[[Governance]] *[[Procurement]] *Integrated project management *Financial viability *Economic viability
==== Technical aspects ====
*Demonstrated need and strategic fit *Siting and design *Hydrological resource *Asset reliability and efficiency *Infrastructure safety
The Protocol also includes ‘cross-cutting issues’ such as [[climate change]], [[gender]], and [[human rights]], which feature in multiple topics.
=== Criteria === For each sustainability topic, performance is assessed against a range of criteria at two levels: basic good practice and proven best practice.
==== Table 2: Criteria requirement at different levels. ==== {| class="wikitable" ! '''Criteria'''
! '''Basic Good Practice'''
! '''Proven Best Practice'''
|- | '''Assessment'''
| Adequate and effective assessment of the issues
| The assessment takes a broad view of the issues.
No significant opportunities for improvement.
|- | '''Management'''
| Adequate and effective management plans and processes
| Plans can anticipate and respond to new issues and opportunities.
No significant opportunities for improvement.
|- | '''Stakeholder Engagement'''
| Adequate and effective stakeholder engagement
| Project is inclusive and participatory. Feedback is provided. Stakeholders involved in decision-making.
No significant opportunities for improvement.
|- | '''Stakeholder Support'''
| General support amongst directly affected stakeholder groups
| Support of nearly all directly affected stakeholder groups.
In cases, formal agreements with consent of directly affected stakeholder groups.
|- | '''Conformance and Compliance'''
| No significant non-compliances and non-conformances
| No non-compliances and non-conformances.
|- | '''Outcomes'''
| Impacts are avoided, minimised, and mitigated, with no significant gaps
| Impacts are also compensated, and the project enhances pre-project conditions.
|}
== History == A multi-stakeholder forum developed the Protocol between 2008 and 2010.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hydropower Sustainability - History|url = http://www.hydrosustainability.org/Protocol/Protocol-development.aspx|website = www.hydrosustainability.org|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref>
The following key group were represented: social and environmental NGOs, governments of developed and developing countries, financial institutions, development banks, and the hydropower industry.
The forum jointly reviewed, enhanced and built consensus on what a sustainable hydropower project should look like.
Policies taken into account included the [[World Commission on Dams]]’ Criteria and Guidelines, World Bank Safeguard Policies, IFC Performance Standards, and the [[Equator Principles]].
A draft of the Protocol was released in 2009, which was trialled in 16 countries across six continents and subjected to further consultation involving 1,933 individual stakeholders from 28 countries.
The final version was produced in 2010.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hydropower Sustainability - Download Protocol Document|url = http://www.hydrosustainability.org/Protocol/The-Protocol-Documents.aspx|website = www.hydrosustainability.org|accessdate = 2015-09-30}}</ref>
The diversity of the forum was important to ensure that the Protocol became globally applicable and universally accepted. Diversity also ensured that the multiple perspectives and stakeholder interests surrounding a hydropower project were incorporated into the document.
== Governance == The Protocol is governed by a multi-stakeholder body, the Hydropower Sustainability Assessment Council (HSA Council).<ref>http://www.hydrosustainability.org/Governance.aspx</ref>
The mission of the Council is to ensure multi-stakeholder input and confidence in the Protocol's content and application.
All individuals and organisations engaged in hydropower are welcome and encouraged to join the Council. This approach to governance ensures that all stakeholder voices are heard in the shaping of the use of the Protocol and its future development.
The Council consists of a series of Chambers, each representing a different segment of hydropower stakeholders. Each chamber elects a chair and alternate chair for a two-year term. The chamber chairs come together regularly to form the decision-making Protocol Governance Committee. The current Governance Committee (elected May 2015) is shown in the table below.
